title: Kicking off with some websites!
content:
COMPILERS
[url=http://www.mingw.org/]MinG/W[/url] - a compiler environment for Windows (2k/XP at least), available for free. Requires knowledge of shell scripting and *ix (at least the basics). Based upon...

[url=http://gcc.gnu.org/]The GNU Compiler Collection[/url] aka GCC. As the name implies, a collection of compilers - from C and C++ to Pascal, and several others. If you're using Linux or some other *ixes, this should be the default compiler you're using.

[url=http://www.cygwin.com/]CygWin[/url] - another Windows (2k/XP) GCC-based compiler solution. Like MinG/W, requires basic knowledge of shell scripting.

LIBRARIES
[url=http://www.allegro.cc/]Allegro[/url] - a library, comprising of graphics, sound and music support. This has been used in commercially available stuff (I've seen it in use, for example, on a quiz machine in a local pub!), so it's quality is not in doubt. Extensible (supports OpenGL, for example).

[url=http://www.libsdl.org/]SDL[/url] - again, used in commercial quality software. Lower-level emphasis than Allegro - decent sound support, for example, requires the SDL_Mixer addon library. Extensible (supports OpenGL, for example).

[url=http://www.lua.org/]Lua[/url] - a scripting language that can be embedded into other programs, thus affording them a greater level of extendibility.

ART SOFTWARE
[url=http://www.gimp.org/]The GIMP[/url] - a Photoshop-level free graphics package.

Just a small sample there, hope they help someone!

title: Some more links.
content:

title: Re: -
content:
by coding in support for AdPlug

Or you could just borrow MAME's OPL synth and write your own IMF player (mine's only about a dozen lines of code, the format's that simplistic.) Providing you can stream digital audio out the speakers on the fly, that'll let you play IMF files.

Seriously though, getting instruments from an Adlib file shouldn't be this hard?

The problem is that IMF files don't technically store the instruments. If you're working with MODs then you'll be thinking of a dedicated section of the file for instruments/samples, and then when you play a note you select which instrument to use. IMF works at a much lower level, it only stores all the values sent to the OPL chip on the sound card, and when you stream these values one at a time back to the card, music comes out.

If you want to find out which instrument is being used, you have to work your way through the file and check every byte being sent out, to see whether it's related to setting the instrument - I can't remember the numbers exactly, but basically data sent to register 0x60 sets one tiny part of the instrument, register 0x80 sets something else, but register 0xB0 actually plays a note. You'll have to gather up all the values for the instrument registers, then write them out in a known format. The problem is that there's nothing stopping a song from playing notes in between setting instruments, or twiddling with the instrument settings while the song is playing, in effect using thousands of slightly different instruments. In practice this rarely happens, but it's something any converter would have to handle.

I have thought of another way of getting the instruments out - if you can find that IMF2MID program I posted about years ago, run that on the IMF file. It will print all the port settings for each instrument to the screen, so all you have to do then is write down those values and save them in a certain format. Look up the .IBK (Instrument Bank) format, that stores a whole bunch of Adlib instruments, and if you can convert IMF2MID's output into an .IBK file then you can load it in SBTimbre and use that to play single notes. You'll want to be at least a little familiar with how the OPL chips work to do that successfully though.
